documentMetadata.title: Definitive therapy of septic arthritis caused by hemolytic and non-hemolytic streptococci

items: Definitive therapy of septic arthritis caused by hemolytic and non-hemolytic streptococci
Signs and symptoms of septic arthritis.
Gram strain positive for Gram-positive cocci in chains and/or positive synovial fluid or blood culture for streptococci.

procedureData.name: Drainage or debridement
procedureData.notes: In addition to antimicrobial therapy, drainage or debridement should always be performed by needle aspiration (repeated as needed), arthroscopy, or arthrotomy.

regimenData.notes: to achieve preferred target AUC24 400-600 µg/mL x hr (see vancomycin AUC dosing calculator; alternative is trough level of 15-20 µg/mL)

items: Large series of streptococcal prosthetic joint infection managed with debridement, implant retention, and antibiotics found a failure rate of 42% (Clin Infect Dis 2017;64:1742).
Predictors of failure were rheumatoid arthritis, late post-surgical infection (> 3 months), bacteremia, infection with S. pyogenes.
Predictors of success were exchange of removable components, use of rifampin within the first 30 days, a prolonged course (>21 days) of a beta-lactam antibiotic with or without Rifampin.
Role of oral step-down therapy is unclear; potentially effective agents include Linezolid 600 mg po bid, Clindamycin 600 mg po tid, or Amoxicillin 1 gm po tid.
